items.title: Scientists make yogurt using ants. The result: tangy and herby
bullets: • Scientists make yogurt using ants
• The result: tangy and herby
• The research team said the yogurt was just barely clumpy at the bottom of the jar
• That's because the ants have their own microbiome that includes lactic acid used in fermentation

items.title: Iceland reports the presence of mosquitoes for the first time, as climate warms
bullets: • Iceland reports the presence of mosquitoes for the first time in its history
• The discovery of three Culiseta annulata mosquitoes was confirmed by the Natural Science Institute of Iceland
• Antarctica is now the only place in the world believed to have no mosquitoes

items.title: ‘We found 23,000 worms!’ The soil project bringing life back to the land
bullets: • Soil is the second largest carbon store after the oceans, but it’s being steadily degraded
• Deforestation, intensive agriculture, urbanisation and pollution have decimated the soil
• One farming community is pioneering a soil health project to show how organic regenerative agriculture can restore this vital ecosystem

items.title: What does patriotism mean to you?
bullets: • We want to know what stirs a sense of belonging in the place you call home
• What connects you to the land you live in and your fellow citizens? We'll read every response and share a selection of them in a forthcoming editorial
• Too often, patriotism has been used as a tool of division rather than unity - defined from podium rather than people

items.title: Found Footage Horror ‘Project Butterfly: Flatwoods’ Coming Halloween Night 2025!
bullets: • Project Butterfly: Flatwoods is a found footage horror film set during the lunar eclipse of 2004, in Flatwoods, West Virginia
• The film follows three students who are filming a school project centered around an investigation that eventually leads them to a government bunker connected to cryptid experimentation
• The further the students dig, the more they uncover the terrifying truths of this bunker

items.title: Judge extends ban on Trump firing federal workers during government shutdown
bullets: • Judge Susan Illston extended a temporary order blocking the Trump administration's plans to fire thousands of federal employees during the government shutdown
• The order, called a preliminary injunction, prohibits the administration from issuing reduction-in-force notices until the government reopens
• President Donald Trump has said the shutdown gives his administration an "opportunity" to slash what he has described as "Democrat Agencies"

items.title: Jamaicans take shelter as Hurricane Melissa bears down as category 5 storm
bullets: • Hurricane Melissa is the strongest hurricane to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851
• It is set to make landfall early on Tuesday and to linger over the island
• Forecasters warn of catastrophic flooding, landslides and extensive infrastructure damage
• Some parts of eastern Jamaica could receive up to a metre (40in) of rain

items.title: Two crucial Florida coral species left ‘functionally extinct’ by ocean heatwave
bullets: • Two of the most important coral species that made up Florida’s reef are now functionally extinct after a withering ocean heatwave caused catastrophic losses
• The “functional extinction” is a stage before global extinction, a threat that now looms for many coral species
• Scientists this month warned that a tipping point had been reached whereby corals around the world are set to be wiped out

• The finding helps validate decades of solar physics theories

items.title: Melting ice is hiding a massive climate secret beneath Antarctica
bullets: • The Southern Ocean absorbs nearly half of all ocean-stored human CO2, but its future role is uncertain
• Fresh, low-salinity water near the surface has helped trap carbon in the deep ocean, slowing its return to the atmosphere
• Climate change is steadily altering these delicate ocean layers and could soon disrupt this natural carbon storage system

items.title: Ancient tides may have sparked humanity’s first urban civilization
bullets: • New research shows that the rise of Sumer was deeply tied to the tidal and sedimentary dynamics of ancient Mesopotamia
• Early communities harnessed predictable tides for irrigation, but when deltas cut off the Gulf’s tides, they faced crisis and reinvented their society
• This interplay of environment and culture shaped Sumer's myths, politics, and innovations
